Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 02:10PM - edited Jun 28, 2009 02:14PM by Solarbeam I was diagnosed at a stage IIa May 21, 09.  So far we figure the cancer has been removed surgically on June 18, 09, however I don't get the pathology report back until July 2, 09 to know that for sure.  My oncologist says I don't absolutely need TC chemo, but is recomending it to be on the safe side.  My first treatment is on July 8, 09.  I feel good about my decission to go ahead with the treatments, but I'm still scared at times.  I'm not looking forward to losing my hair, it's been long for most of my life and I love it.  I heard that taking mega doses of vit E a week before treatments can lessen the chances of hair loss.  I'll be keeping in touch with this site regularly to share my thoughts.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 05:03PM Solarbeam wrote: cherneski - Yes, it is a lot of surgeries, but I'm hearing that many women don't go through with all the reconstruction. My first was a lumpectomy with 10 nodes removed.  The margins weren't clear, but my nodes were.  I was back in for a second surgery 3 weeks later for a subcutaneous mastectomy.  Margins were clear that time. Then I had 4 rounds of TC. After the chemo, I was back in surgery for a third surgery for a full mastectomy.  I decided keeping a nipple wasn't worth the risk even though margins were clear.  I had invasive ductal cancer. I'll be in radiation in about 3 week or so for 6 weeks. Once I've healed from that, I'll be in my 4th surgery.  I'm having a mastectomy on the other breast (which is medically unnecessary, but psychologically and cosmetically to my benefit).  I'll also have tissue expanders put in at this point. My 5th surgery will be to replace the tissue expanders with implants.   My 6th surgery will be to have nipples put back on.  Yippee!  How exciting that will be! Of course, once I heal from that, I'll be back in for the colour. I was warned at the beginning of all this that it would be a long journey with many steps.  However, I'm looking forward to the big journey being so much longer - the journey we call life. God Bless.
Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 03:52PM Solarbeam wrote: I just got out of my third surgery 2 days ago.  I'll be starting radiation in about 3 weeks.  My lymphs were clear, the tumor was removed completely, and went back for a full mastectomy anyway.  I went through 4 rounds of TC and I'm free and clear, but my oncology team wants to treat with 6 weeks of radiation anyway.  I don't really know what to expect, but I'll be looking forward to the reconstruction part of this whole thing.  God Bless.
Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 04:00AM Solarbeam wrote: Hey everyone!  I'm going in today (November 4) for my radiation tattoos and expect to start the radiation treatment November 23.  I'm told 6 weeks, so I insisted no later than November 23 start date because that will take me to the end of December and I'm planning full time nursing school in January.  I was going to start in September, but with radiation being every day for many weeks, I decided to put it off a semister so I wouldn't miss so much school. I went for my H1N1 shot yesterday and a woman there said she was diagnosed 6 years ago and told me that the tattoo in the center of the chest was painful.  I remember reading that here from someone as well.  I have 2 tattoos from year ago, and somehow I've not needed any pain medicine for the past 3 surgeries that I've had, and the nucular die injection didn't even hurt at all, so I guess I'll find out today about the radiation tattoos and let you know. I sure am looking forward to my next surgery once radiation is all done.  They're going to remove my left breast (which is completely healthy) to match the right side and put in tissue expanders.  I'll be even again and on the next step to having new boobies! I'm wondering how long most of you ladies who have had tissue expanders had to wait between radiation and having the tissue expanders put in?  Thanks everyone.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2009 08:57AM Solarbeam wrote: Okay, it's day 18 now of the first treatment.  Day 16 some of my hair came out.  As of day 17 all but about 10% of my hair is now gone.  I was going to have my sister buzz the rest of it off last night, but I couldn't go through with it.  I'm sure the rest will be gone in the next day or two, but I couldn't give it up last night.  My sister says she wouldn't have been able to go through with it either, and that vodka was the answer.
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Solarbeam wrote: I just started my first treatment of TC on July 8.  No reactions during the treatment, no major side effects since then.  A little tired off and on over days 3 and 4, and a bit yukky feeling, but that's all.  I think my biggest complaint so far is that everything tastes like metal, even water.  I got a craving for something sweet, thougth I'd give it a try, and Starburst candies actually taste like candies!  Overall, I seem to be handling it all quite well.  Not nearly as bad feeling as I was expecting from what everyone has been telling me.  I hope whomever is about to start TC may read this and feel better about what's to come.  I'll let you know what round 2 is like for me.  God Bless.  xo Life is not about waiting for the storm clouds to pass. It's about learning to dance in the rain. Dx 5/21/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/10 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 06:41PM Solarbeam wrote: Hi dogsaver, Karenvw, and everyone else.  I haven't been on here in a while.  Treatments have been pretty good to me for the most part, but I've been dealing with the loss of my mother who passed a few weeks ago.  I made it through 4 rounds of TC and decided to have further surgery.  My first surgery was just a lumpectomy with the removal of 10 nodes.  Second surgery was 3 weeks later for a subcutaneous (nipple sparing) mastectomy.  Then came the chemo.  And now I've decided to have the nipple removed before radiation.  Once radiation is done, I'll be back in surgery for a complete mastectomy on the other side.  (Although not medically necessary, my oncology team has agreed that psychologically and cosmetically it would be better for me and are supporting this decission.)  At that time, I'll be having tissue expanders put into place.  Then of course, another surgery to replace them with implants.  Then I think I would like to go back and have some nipples again.  Some people are telling me that I may not want to, but I can't imagine not going through the entire reconstructive surgery. As far as my hair, well most of it came out on day 17 of round 1, but not all of it.  I've lost a few strands slowly over the weeks since then, but always have some at the back.  I had my chemo every 3 weeks, and at just over 3 weeks after my last treatment, I had some hair coming back.  It's now been 6 weeks since my last treatment and I have about an inch or so of hair already and it's filling in every day.  It's very exciting, however my hair was down to my waist before chemo so it will take me a while before I get it all back again.  At least now I have the rest of my life. Again, I will say, that anyone about to get TC for their treatments, it's really not bad at all.  In fact, I felt great on my chemo treatments (other than day 4 where I felt a bit yukky), my allergies weren't irritating me, my skin was great, everyone said I was glowing.  Just make sure you get the Nupogen injections. God Bless.
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 09:10AM Solarbeam wrote: Today is day 8 for me now.  I've actually felt so much back to normal since day 5 that I've been so busy all week and I almost miss the mild tired yukky feeling just for an excuse to have a nap during the day and avoid all the house work and other things to do.  Guess I'm not very good at milking the situation.  Maybe I'll learn for next time if it goes this well again.  Good luck to you all ladies!  God bless.
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2009 01:47PM Solarbeam wrote: Today is day 20 of my first treatment.  Looking back on my post from July 25 (day 18), I lost about 90% of my hair the day before and got my sister to come over and we almost buzzed the rest off.  Well since then, I've hardly lost any of the remaining 10% that I have left.  Am I ever glad we didn't buzz it all off.  My second treatment is the day after tomorrow, and I'm wondering how long the rest will last.  Has anyone else had a similar situation where the hair loss has slowed down or stopped and they got to keep the rest of it?  I'm not worried about the other side effects of treatment, as they hardly touched me at all for round one.  Hope there are others with the same experience there.  Best wishes to all.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 06:45AM Solarbeam wrote: Today is my second treatment of TC.  For me, the T is Taxotere and the C is Cytoxan.  I had very minimal side effects.  No nausia, no vomiting, only a couple mild stomach cramps that lasted no more than a few minutes, no fever, just the metal taste in my mouth and a bit of a white tongue - that went away in about 2 or 3 days.  Have you tried the Biotene, or maybe baking soda or salt in some water?  (1 teaspoon in 250ml of water).  Or hydrogen peroxide and water rinse?  (1 part water to 4 parts hydrogen peroxide).  This was all on my info sheet that I got from my oncology team.  I just kept up on the Biotene and it went away in a couple of days, but with how little side effects I had anyway, this might have not made a difference to me.  Try doing these rinses every 2 hours and maybe it will help. Good luck to you all.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2009 10:11PM - edited Aug 1, 2009 10:12PM by Solarbeam Hi ssimmons.  I started losing my hair on day 15 and 16 of round 1, but not too much then.  Probably at least 50% of it came out on day 17.  I thought all along that I would buzz it all off when that day came, but I couldn't go through with it.  On day 18, and since then, I've gone back to only losing strands.  I have to say that I'm glad I never buzzed it off, especially because I had such long hair, but it is shorter now just because of the longer hair is what came out.  I know there's not much left now, and it could all fall out by day 17 of round 2 (I'm on day 4 of round 2 now), but it's still my hair and I want to have what I have.  Everyone is trying to tell me what I should or shouldn't do about it.  Don't let anyone tell you what you should do, or how you should do it, or when you should have it done.  It's your hair, and your situation, and all you need from them is their support on whatever you decide to do about it.   My daughter isn't into my wearing a wig, she's only 3, and I think she prefers the scarf.  My son is 8 and says I should do what I want to do, but he prefers when I wear a scarf just because of how thin my hair is now.  I think my husband would prefer if I were to at least cut what's left of it, just so it's not as messy if the rest will eventually come out, but he knows better than to say anything or tell me what to do.  Smart man. God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 08:03AM Solarbeam wrote: Today is day 8 of round 2 for me now.  I felt some more body aches and yukkiness on day 4 more with round 2 than day 4 of round 1, but I still did all my housework, homework, played with my kids, etc.  By the evening of day 4 I started to feel better, but day 5 I wasn't quite back to normal as I was on day 5 of round 1.  Also, I didn't feel as tired this time around.  Maybe I just don't have time to be tired, but I think a nap still would have been nice. I also wanted to make a comment to some of the women who are having a hard time deciding whether or not to have treatment if it's offered as a choice.  My oncologist said I could turn it down if I really wanted to (I am cancer free as of my last surgery and my lymphs were clear), but she highly recommended I have the treatments to make sure I stay that way.  I'm 35.  I never had an oncotype test done.  I jumped at the offer to have chemo because this isn't something that I'd want to regret later on.  Especially because I have young kids who need me to be here for them.  What's a few days of not feeling great and a few month of growing hair back compared to seeing your own children smile every day and knowing you helped put the smile there.  It's no decission, it's living your life.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 07:24AM Solarbeam wrote: Well today is day 15 of round 1 for me and I still have hair.  Days 13 and 14 it's been coming out, but not enough for anyone to notice by looking at me.  I wonder what will happen.  I have long hair that hangs well past the bottom of my shoulder blades and I'm not at the point where I want to cut it all off just because I've lost a few strands.  I guess we'll see over the next few days. My first treatment went very well, not sick at all, in fact I've been living my life as usual since day 5.  I even went to Niagara Falls for a few days and had a blast.  My biggest complaint was that everything tasted like metal, but that started fading after about a week.  Now I can taste sweet things, and everything else is pretty flavorless. Another week until my second treatment.  I'll let you know how it goes and if I still have hair by then.  My best wishes to everyone.  God bless.  xo
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2009 03:22PM Solarbeam wrote: They never offered me a port, but if they did, I still would have went with IV.  It's only in for 3 hours, then I don't have to deal with it again until next round, 3 weeks later. I had 16mg Decadron twice a day, for 3 days, starting the day before chemo. I had 4mg Kytril, once a day, for 3 days, starting day of chemo. They also gave me 10mg Stemetil to take every 4 hours if needed, but I haven't need it at all. I'm also on Neuprogen SC injection, once a day, for 7 days, starting the day after chemo.  This helps bones produce the WBC's to fight possible infection.  I've had some pain in my leg bones from them working overtime, but worth not having to lock myself in a bubble during treatment. Days 3 and 4 I felt pretty yukky, but not too bad.  Today is day 5 for me, and I'm feeling pretty much back to normal.  Good luck with everything.  I wish you my best.
Posts.Title: TC X 4 Solarbeam Solarbeam
